posts.title: 99 francs
posts.excerpt: A first person diatribe against modern consumerist society as seen through the eyes of a cynical advertising executive whose efforts to get fired from his job backfire as he keeps getting promoted.

posts.title: Thérèse Desqueyroux
posts.excerpt: The unhappily married woman struggles to break free from social pressures and her boring suburban setting.

posts.excerpt: SynopsisHis film In This House, 2005 records the search in the garden of a house in southern Lebanon for a letter encased and buried there by a former National Front resistance fighter who had occupied the house in the early 1980s. Camp Thiaroye (1988), cowritten and codirected by Thierno Faty Sow, recounts an incident that occurred in 1944. posts.title: Dreileben – Eine Minute Dunkel
posts.excerpt: The Dreileben trilogy comes to a nail-biting close with director Christoph Hochhäusler’s expert thriller, which also brings escaped felon Molosch—a peripheral character in the first two parts—into sharp focus. posts.title: La Vie, l’amour, la mort
posts.excerpt: Review SummaryThe title Life Love Death (originally La Vie, L’amour, la Mort) pretty much runs the gamut of the subject matter which normally appeals to French filmmaker Claude Lelouch.
